_header: Nas there never carion so loath
Bibliographic Ghosts: Cambridge UK, St John’s College F.22 (159)
_description: The loathesomeness of Death, a tag in the Fasciculus morum freely rendering a quotation attributed to St. Bernard — six lines roughly rhyming aabccb

BodLauMis213.Transcription:
naster euer careyn so lothas mon When he to pyt gotheand deth
                    hatȝ layd so loghffor when dethe draghetȝ mon from
                    eyereþe soster wol not se þe brodyrno fadyr þe sone
                    knawe

BodLauMis111.Transcription:
Naster nower karoyn so loth as man wen he to pyt gothand deth
                    hath leyd so loghFor won deth drauth man to þe ertheþi
                    suster nil nouth seo þe brotherne fader ye þi sone ys
                    knowe

Bod410.First Lines:
Naster neuer careyn so lothos man when he to put
                    goth…
Bod410.Last Lines:
…þe suster nyl not se þe brotherne fader þe
                    sone knowe

BodRawC670.Transcription:
Was þer neuer caren so lotheAs mon when he to put gothAnd
                    deth has layde so loweFor when deth drawes mon from oþurþe
                    suster nul not se þe brotherNe fader þe sone i knawe
BodRawC670.Editions:
Wenzel,  Siegfried. 
             Verses in Sermons: ‘Fasciculus morum’ and Its Middle
                English Poems.
         Cambridge, MA: Medieval Academy of America, 1978: 149.

EDU82.Transcription:
Waster neuer caryon so lotheas man when he to the pytte gotheand
                    dethe hathe layde so laweffor whan dethe draws men fro otherthe syster
                    wull not se the brotherne fader the son knawe

Lincoln44.Transcription:
Was þar neuer caroyne so loythas manne wene ho to pute
                    goþand deþ haþ leyd so low deþ for wanne draw
                    þy manne fro oþersuster vl noght se þi broþerne
                    þe fader þe sonne þi kauwe
